<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-_xxx skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">.xxx</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_Top_level_domain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox Top level domain (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox Top level domain</a>
</p><p><b>.xxx</b> (pronounced "dot triple-<a href="/wiki/X_rating" title="X rating">X</a>" or "dot x x x") is a <a href="/wiki/Sponsored_top-level_domain" title="Sponsored top-level domain">sponsored top-level domain</a> (sTLD) intended as a voluntary option for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pornography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pornography (page does not exist)">pornographic</a> sites on the Internet. The sponsoring organization is the International Foundation for Online Responsibility (IFFOR).<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> The registry is operated by ICM Registry LLC. The <a href="/wiki/ICANN" title="ICANN">ICANN</a> Board voted to approve the sTLD on 18 March 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> It went into operation on 15 April 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>The TLD entered its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunrise_period&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunrise period (page does not exist)">sunrise period</a> on 7 September 2011 at 16:00 UTC;<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> the sunrise period ended 28 October 2011. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Landrush_period&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Landrush period (page does not exist)">Landrush period</a> lasted from 8 November through 25 November, and General Availability commenced on 6 December 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Background"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Background</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#ICANN_.2F_ICM"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">ICANN / ICM</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Manwin_suits"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Manwin suits</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Alternative_implementations"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Alternative implementations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-7"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h2>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/GTLD" title="GTLD" class="mw-redirect">gTLD</a> (generic top-level domain) for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sexually_explicit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sexually explicit (page does not exist)">sexually explicit</a> material was proposed as one tool for dealing with the conflict between those who wish to provide and access such material through the Internet, and those who wish to prevent access to it, either by children and <a href="/wiki/Adolescence" title="Adolescence">adolescents</a>, or by employees at their workplaces.
</p><p>Advocates of the idea argue that it will be easier for parents and employers to block the entire TLD, rather than using more complex and error-prone content-based filtering, without imposing any restrictions on those who wish to access it.<sup id="cite_ref-ynot_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ynot-6">[6]</a></sup> Editors of explicit content sites, however, were afraid that the use of a single TLD like <code>.xxx</code> would also make it easier for search engines to block all of their content.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Critics of the idea argue that because there is no requirement for providers of explicit content to use the TLD, sexually explicit material will still be commonplace in other domains, making it ineffectual at restricting access, and simply creating a new "landrush" as registrants of .com domains hosting explicit material attempt to duplicate their registrations in the <code>.xxx</code> domain, competing with operators who hope to register desirable names unavailable in other TLDs. There is also concern that the existence of <code>.xxx</code> will lead to legislation making its use <i>mandatory</i> for sexually explicit material, leading to legal conflicts over the definition of "sexually explicit", free speech rights, and jurisdiction.<sup id="cite_ref-ynot_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ynot-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is also early evidence that <code>.xxx</code> domain names will be registered not with the intent to focus on pornographic content, but to use the adult connotations as a benefit to a marketing strategy.<sup id="cite_ref-mash_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mash-9">[9]</a></sup>  An example is the registration of <code>kite.xxx</code>, which is aimed at the extreme sport of <a href="/wiki/Kitesurfing" title="Kitesurfing">kitesurfing</a>, thus benefiting from sexual connotations and innuendo for humor and promotional purposes.  Another example of a <code>.xxx </code> domain name being registered without a focus on pornographic content was the registration of <code>popebenedict.xxx</code>, which contained pro-Islamic content despite being named after <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="ICANN_.2F_ICM">ICANN / ICM</span></h2>
<p>The .XXX TLD was first proposed in 2000 by ICM Registry and resubmitted in 2004, but it faced strong opposition from politicians and conservative groups.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>ICANN announced on 1 June 2005 a preliminary approval of <code>.xxx</code> as an sTLD similar to <code><a href="/wiki/.aero" title=".aero">.aero</a></code>, <code><a href="/wiki/.travel" title=".travel">.travel</a></code>, etc. ICM said it would charge $60/year for domains.  In December 2005, discussions about the implementation of <code>.xxx</code> were taken off the agenda of ICANN Governmental Advisory Committee (GAC), placing its future in doubt. In its March 2006 meeting, the GAC formulated a letter of concern to the ICANN board about <code>.xxx</code>. On 10 May 2006, ICANN reversed the approval.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> On 6 January 2007, ICANN put up for public comment a revised proposal<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> following changes to the policy of the ICM registry including the policing of any site that signs up to use the <code>.xxx</code> registry.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> On 30 March 2007, the ICANN board again rejected the <code>.xxx</code> proposal for the third time.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 6 June 2008, in accordance with ICANN bylaws, ICM filed an application for an independent review challenging ICANN's decision, and in September 2009, a live hearing was held in Washington DC, where both sides submitted documentary evidence and witness testimony. on 19 February 2010 ICANN's Independent Review Panel (IRP) issued its findings. The Panel found that the application for the ".XXX sTLD met the required sponsorship criteria," and that "the Board’s reconsideration of that finding was not consistent with the application of neutral, objective and fair documented policy".<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> At the ICANN meeting in Nairobi in March 2010 the board resolved to consider "process options". A 45-day public comment was opened on 26 March 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-feb_2010_announcement_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-feb_2010_announcement-17">[17]</a></sup> At the Brussels ICANN meeting in June 2010, the ICANN board resolved to restart the process, including renewed due diligence and GAC consultations.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 18 March 2011, ICANN's board approved the execution of the registry agreement with ICM for the <code>.xxx</code> sponsored top level domain. The vote was 9 in favor, 4 against, with 3 abstentions.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>ICM is expected to make over $200 million a year, with 3 to 5 million domain registrations, as companies are anticipated to defensively register their domains.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Manwin_suits">Manwin suits</span></h2>
<p>On 16 November 2011, Manwin Licensing International, a company that operates several popular adult websites including <a href="/w/index.php?title=YouPorn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="YouPorn (page does not exist)">YouPorn</a>, filed a request for a 2nd ICANN Independent Review Proceeding. In the request Manwin asks that the .xxx delegation be voided, or, if not, put up to competition on renewal.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the same day Manwin, together with adult film studio <a href="/wiki/Digital_Playground" title="Digital Playground">Digital Playground</a>, filed a suit in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_District_of_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central District of California (page does not exist)">Central District of California</a> against ICM alleging <a href="/wiki/Sherman_Antitrust_Act" title="Sherman Antitrust Act">antitrust</a> and <a href="/wiki/Competition_law" title="Competition law">competition</a> violations.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CourtDocket_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CourtDocket-23">[23]</a></sup> Among the claims in the suit are that ICANN provided "no competitive process for the award of the .<b>XXX</b> registry contract" and that ICM CEO Stuart Lawley "has announced that he expects to be able (and intends) to prevent the establishment of any other (potentially competing) adult-content TLDs, including through a contractual promise by ICANN not to approve such TLDs".<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 14, 2012, judge Philip S. Gutierrez granted in part and denied in part ICANN's motion to dismiss Manwin's claims and allowed the case against ICANN to move forward.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> On May 10, 2013, the case was voluntarily dismissed by the parties, likely due to private settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-CourtDocket_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CourtDocket-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Alternative_implementations">Alternative implementations</span></h2>
<p>Starting in 2005, there was an alternative implementation of <code>.xxx</code> by <a href="/wiki/New.net" title="New.net">New.net</a>, a private domain registration service unaffiliated with ICANN, via an <a href="/wiki/Alternative_DNS_root" title="Alternative DNS root">alternative DNS root</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> New.net no longer offers domain names under this unofficial TLD.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Or&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Or (page does not exist)">Template:Or</a>
</p><p>Another unofficial <code>.xxx</code> TLD was previously available through the alternative DNS root system administered by the now-defunct <a href="/wiki/AlterNIC" title="AlterNIC">AlterNIC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>

</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.icann.org/en/irp/icm-v-icann/icm-icann-history-21feb10-en.pdf">"Chronological History of ICM’s Involvement with ICANN"</a>. ICANN website. (nds with Independent Review Panel declaration of 19 February 2010)
</li>
<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.w3.org/2004/03/28-tld">W3C: Why Using TLDs for Filtering is Ineffective, Harmful, and Unnecessary</a>
</li>
<li> <a class="external mw-magiclink-rfc" rel="nofollow" href="//tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3675">RFC 3675</a> .sex Considered Dangerous
</li>
</ul>

	<h3 id='p-navigation-label'>Navigation</h3>

			<li id="n-featuredcontent"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Featured_content">featuredcontent</a></li>
			<li id="n-currentevents"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Current_events" title="Find background information on current events">Current events</a></li>
			<li id="n-randompage"><a href="/wiki/Special:Random" title="Load a random page [x]" accesskey="x">Random article</a></li>
			<li id="n-sitesupport"><a href="https://donate.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:FundraiserRedirector?utm_source=donate&amp;utm_medium=sidebar&amp;utm_campaign=C13_en.wikipedia.org&amp;uselang=en" rel="nofollow">Donate to Wikipedia</a></li>

<div class="portal" role="navigation" id='p-tb' aria-labelledby='p-tb-label'>
	<h3 id='p-tb-label'>Tools</h3>
	<div class="body">
		<ul>
			<li id="t-whatlinkshere"><a href="/wiki/Special:WhatLinksHere/.xxx" title="A list of all wiki pages that link here [j]" accesskey="j">What links here</a></li>
			<li id="t-recentchangeslinked"><a href="/wiki/Special:RecentChangesLinked/.xxx" title="Recent changes in pages linked from this page [k]" accesskey="k">Related changes</a></li>
			<li id="t-specialpages"><a href="/wiki/Special:SpecialPages" title="A list of all special pages [q]" accesskey="q">Special pages</a></li>
			<li id="t-print"><a href="/w/index.php?title=.xxx&amp;printable=yes" rel="alternate" title="Printable version of this page [p]" accesskey="p">Printable version</a></li>
			<li id="t-permalink"><a href="/w/index.php?title=.xxx&amp;oldid=353324" title="Permanent link to this revision of the page">Permanent link</a></li>
			<li id="t-info"><a href="/w/index.php?title=.xxx&amp;action=info">Page information</a></li>
		</ul>
	</div>
